Issues.Title: Tailwind CSS v4.x (@tailwindcss/oxide) native binary not installing on WSL2 / Win 11 Pro, postinstall script reports success but file is missing.
Issues.Body:
Disclaimer:
This bug report was generated by an AI because I am a beginner and this is way out of my league.
Please be nice. :)
(Its very late, I think I have missed some information, I'll be happy to provide anything required as this is a persistent issue for me. I have fought with ChatGPT and Gemini for 3 hours, providing all verbose outputs etc and they even got frustrated so I am not sure if I have missed something. Gemini made me submit this bug report in the end. Tried with yarn, npm, nvm and npx.)



Problem Description:
"When installing tailwindcss (v4.1.11, which includes @tailwindcss/oxide) on WSL2 (Ubuntu 22.04), the native binary node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/tailwindcss is not created. The postinstall script for @tailwindcss/oxide consistently reports code: 0 (success), but the file is absent."

PS:
01.07. --- I am back onto it, disabled both Norton and Windows Defender (also Public Network) and Gemini confirmed the following:
"Therefore, the problem is absolutely, 100% with npm's process of handling that binary during installation."
-----
Firewalls still disabled, after "npm install @tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu@4.1.11 --verbose" Gemini says:
"This confirms the hang is happening during the phase where npm transitions from fetching package metadata to actually downloading the content (the .tgz files) of those specific oxide and lightningcss binary packages."
--> it finished after some time, again with Exit-Code "0". Still no progress. Created a /bin in the project directory now and trying to manually fetch the binary. --> after 20 minutes Gemini was not able to locate a binary for manual download, seems like it is straight up impossible to get Tailwind to work on WSL2. Looking for an alternative of setting it up with Symfony and Vue now.
-----
Last edit for now, this is the summary of Gemini after roughly 5 hours in total of trying to get Tailwind to work on WSL2.
After cd'ing to the .npm-directory and "find ~/tailwind_test_isolated/node_modules -type f -name "*tailwindcss-linux-x64*" 2>/dev/null" it confirms the binary indeed did not get downloaded anywhere on the disk.


Let's clarify what's actually happening based on all the logs:

The binary is downloading: Your previous logs explicitly show npm http fetch GET 200 https://registry.npmjs.org/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/-/oxide-linux-x64-gnu-4.1.11.tgz. This means the tarball containing the tailwindcss-linux-x64 executable is successfully being fetched to npm's cache. So, the binary exists and can be downloaded.

The problem is in the postinstall script: The @tailwindcss/oxide package has a postinstall script (node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide/scripts/install.js) that is supposed to extract this downloaded binary from the cache and place it into the correct location within your node_modules (likely node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide/dist/). The critical issue is that this script is reporting code: 0 (success) but is silently failing to actually perform this extraction/placement on your system.

npx tailwindcss won't work anyway (for v4 alpha): Even if the binary were placed correctly, the tailwindcss v4 packages do not include the standard bin field in their package.json files. This means npm and npx have no instruction on how to create a symlink or execute a command called tailwindcss. So, npx tailwindcss will always give "could not determine executable to run" with these alpha v4 packages, regardless of the binary's presence.

Therefore, the problem boils down to: Why is the @tailwindcss/oxide/scripts/install.js script failing silently to extract and place the binary after it's downloaded?

Issues.Title: Issue with Tailwind CSS Installation (Version 4.1.11) — Resolved with Version 3.4.1
Issues.Body:
# v4.1.11 missing CLI binary — `npx tailwindcss init` fails with "could not determine executable to run"

## What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?

**v4.1.11**

## What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?

None – standard npm setup, no additional frameworks or build tools. CLI used manually.

## What version of Node.js are you using?

**v22.15.0**

## What browser are you using?

N/A – CLI issue, browser not involved.

## What operating system are you using?

**Windows 11 (Build 26100)**


## Describe your issue

Hello Tailwind team,

I’m encountering an issue with Tailwind CSS version `v4.1.11` that prevents usage of the CLI via `npx`. After installing this version in a new project using:

```
npm install -D tailwindcss@4.1.11
````

… I attempted to run the following:

```
npx tailwindcss init
```

However, this consistently fails with the error:

```
npm ERR! could not determine executable to run
```

### Investigation Findings:

* The `tailwindcss` binary is **missing** from the `node_modules/.bin` directory.
* Running `npm view tailwindcss@4.1.11 bin` returns **an empty result**, indicating that the published package may be missing the `bin` field in its `package.json`.
* This behavior is **not present** in `v3.4.1`. After downgrading with:

  ```
  npm install -D tailwindcss@3.4.1
  ```

  … the CLI binary is correctly registered, and the following works:

  ```
  npx tailwindcss init
  ```

### Summary:

It appears that version `v4.1.11` of Tailwind CSS was published **without the CLI binary entry**, which breaks usage via `npx`, `npm exec`, or any other CLI-based workflows. This may have been an unintentional omission during publishing.

Please let me know if this was an intentional change or a packaging mistake. If needed, I’m happy to share logs, reproduce this issue further, or help test fixes.

Thanks for your time and continued work on Tailwind!

Best regards,
Prabhat
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Issue with Tailwind CSS Installation (Version 4.1.11) — Resolved with Version 3.4.1" (#18415)

Issues.Title: Using important automatically applies it to utilites set via @apply in v4
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**
v4.1.11

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Angular and NX, however it can be repro'd in the playground

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v24.2.0

**What browser are you using?**

Zen (runs on a Firefox base)

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/kM1swlss8C Minimal example, but shows the issue that padding utilities do not do anything anymore because the `@apply` is enforcing `!important` when it didn't use to in v3

**Describe your issue**

When importing tailwind and making use of important (i.e. `@import "tailwindcss" important`), v4 seems to automatically apply `!important` to any class that is created with `@apply`.

This did not happen in v3 which allowed me to decide whether I needed it or not when using `@apply`, and simultaneously ensuring that when a utility class is used in CSS (i.e. `p-4`) it overrode any CSS that came before it. This is especially important as I use Angular Material, which forces their styles into the `<head>` earlier than application styles causing them to always win in a priority competition, and this behaviour cannot be changed.

Important being forced on `@apply` rules messes with complex custom classes (if you've ever tried to customise the browser's built-in slider input, you'll understand my pain), wherein instead of having my class reference a CSS variable and have that variable have sensible defaults that can simply be overridden with an inline style, i.e. 
```css
// slider.css
// exerpt from a much large class that has to separately handle mozilla and webkit, because sliders SUCK
.slider {
    // Mozilla track gradient (simulates a "filling" bar)
        @apply [&::-moz-range-track]:bg-linear-to-r [&::-moz-range-track]:from-(--left-bar) [&::-moz-range-track]:via-(--right-bar) [&::-moz-range-track]:to-(--right-bar);
        // Mozilla track value setter (allows 1 variable to control both pats of the fill)
        @apply [&::-moz-range-track]:from-(percentage:--value) [&::-moz-range-track]:via-(percentage:--value) [&::-moz-range-track]:to-100%;
}
```

```html
// some-component.html
<input type="range" max="100" class="slider" [style.--value.%]="value"  [value]="value" />
```

With v4 now I am forced to set the variable with `!important` in order to override the default value I have set at 50%

Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** For example: v3.4.17 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** For example: postcss" 8.5.3, Vite 6.3.5/7.0.0 **What version of Node.js are you using?** For example: v22.11.0 **What browser are you using?** Chrome **What operating system are you using?** macOS **Reproduction URL** https://stackblitz.com/edit/vitejs-vite-tzng15gi?file=index.html,src%2FApp.tsx **Describe your issue** When using Tailwind CSS with custom variants and arbitrary selectors, there's an issue with the order of modifiers affecting whether styles are applied correctly. Specifically, when a variant like `focus-visible:` or `hover:` is placed *before* an arbitrary selector that contains `:not()`, the styles don't get applied. ### Working example: ```html
working
``` ### Non-working examples: ```html
not working
also not working
``` This appears to be related to how the CSS selectors are generated and composed when variants are applied in different orders. The issue occurs with custom variants (like my implementation of `focus-visible`) as well as built-in variants like `hover:`. IntelliSense's hover preview does get it right though: ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b8ecb265-c5ff-46c7-95c6-7ad6d4fac34e) ## Expected behavior Both ordering approaches should work and apply the styles correctly, regardless of whether the variant is placed before or after the arbitrary selector.

Issues.Title: feat: add Vite 7 support to the @tailwindcss/vite plugin
Issues.Body:
Closes #18381 

* [Changelog for Vite 7.0.0 (2025-06-24)](https://github.com/vitejs/vite/blob/main/packages/vite/CHANGELOG.md#700-2025-06-24)

Starting from Vite 7, Node 18 support will be dropped, which doesn't really affect Tailwind. It might be worth mentioning in the documentation that the recommended minimum Node versions are 20.19 and 22.12.

Vite 7 is only available in ESM format, which is also not an issue.

Vite's browser support aligns with the v4 guidelines:
```
Chrome 87 → 107       (tw: 111)
Edge 88 → 107         (tw: 111)
Firefox 78 → 104      (tw: 128)
Safari 14.0 → 16.0    (tw: 16.4)
```
* [Vite 7 - Browser Support](https://vite.dev/guide/migration.html#default-browser-target-change)
* [Tailwind CSS v4 - Browser Support](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/compatibility#browser-support)

So, at first glance, there's nothing more to do except enabling support for these versions.

Issues.Title: `calc-size()` requires two parameters, but Tailwind doesn't work with two arguments
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

`v4.1.6` (problem is also reproducible in the playground using latest version)

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Webpack 5, React 18, PostCSS plugin

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

`v20.10.0`

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome (other browsers do not support this functionality)

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS and Windows

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/t0kpiVIkMI

**Describe your issue**

The first div uses `h-[calc-size(max-content)]` which emits the correct CSS attribute applied (`height: calc-size(max-content)`) but that is an invalid property value since it requires 2 parameters.

The second div uses `h-[calc-size(max-content, size)]` which should emit the CSS attribute `height: calc-size(max-content, size)` which is a valid CSS attribute value in Chrome but Tailwind emits no class name definition for this property.

~~I'm not sure if I'm doing something wrong syntactically here, or if this behaviour is specific to the `calc-size()` implementation within Tailwind, or with multi-parameter CSS function handling within Tailwind.~~

The third div uses `h-[calc-size(max-content,size)]` which _DOES_ work. Could this indicate that spaces aren't valid within expressions and are always treated as separators for properties?

## References

- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/calc-size#parameters

Issues.Title: According to imunifyAV this may contain malware
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

For example: ``` "tailwindcss": "^3.4.0",```

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

For example: ```"vite": "^6.0.11"``` ```"postcss": "^8.4.32"```

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

For example: ```v20.19.0```

**What browser are you using?**

For example: ```Chrome``` ```Safari```

**What operating system are you using?**

For example: ```macOS```

**Reproduction URL**

 - This issue occurs in any Laravel + Tailwind CSS project where server-side builds are run and the server is protected by ImunifyAV malware scanning.

- A minimal reproduction repo is not required here since the issue does not stem from custom project logic but from native Tailwind dependencies downloaded via npm install.

**Describe your issue**

These .node binaries are being flagged by enterprise-grade AV software like ImunifyAV (used on Plesk, CloudLinux, and cPanel-based environments). While we understand these are precompiled performance tools, some transparency or build options would help dev teams avoid security flagging on production servers.

When deploying a Laravel 11 project using Tailwind CSS (via @tailwindcss/oxide) on a production server running ImunifyAV malware scanning, several files in the node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-* directories are repeatedly flagged as malware.

The affected files are native .node binaries such as: 

```node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/oxide.linux-x64-gnu.node```
```node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```

---

 ```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/tailwindcss-oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```
 ```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/tailwindcss-oxide.linux-x64-gnu.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/oxide.linux-x64-gnu.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/tailwindcss-oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/tailwindcss-oxide.linux-x64-gnu.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```

---

🧨 Problem Summary

This isn’t just an issue with Tailwind’s JIT binaries (oxide). Rollup — the JavaScript bundler that many frontend frameworks use (including Vite, which Laravel 11 defaults to) — is also shipping native .node binaries that are being flagged as malware by ImunifyAV.

---

**My Concerns**

Does this make any websites that use this tailwind library to become vulnerable?  ImunifyAV is saying they contain malware. Is it a false positive? On my side I ran the scan about 8 times and it came back with the same thing each time. I have always used tailwind and it would be ashame to have to move away from it due to these security issues.
